{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Good article}} {{Infobox video game | title = Quantum Break | image = Quantum Break cover.jpg | alt = Promotional cover of ''Quantum Break'' featuring the game's protagonist, Jack Joyce | developer = [[Remedy Entertainment]] | publisher = [[Microsoft Studios]] | director = {{Unbulleted list|[[Sam Lake]]|Mikael Kasurinen}} | producer = Miloš Jeřábek | designer = Kyle Rowley | programmer = {{Unbulleted list|Mikko Uromo|Otto Kivling}} | artist = Janne Pulkkinen | writer = {{Unbulleted list|Mikko Rautalahti|Tyler Burton Smith}} | composer = {{Unbulleted list|Petri Alanko|[[John Kaefer]]}} | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[Xbox One]]}} | released = 5 April 2016 | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]], [[third-person shooter]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }}
'''''Quantum Break''''' is a [[science fiction]] [[Action-adventure game|action-adventure]] [[third-person shooter]] [[video game]] developed by [[Remedy Entertainment]] and published by [[Microsoft Studios]]. The game was released worldwide for [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[Xbox One]] in April 2016. The game centers on Jack Joyce, granted time manipulation powers after a failed time-machine experiment, as he comes into conflict with former friend Paul Serene over how to deal with an apocalyptic "End of Time". In addition, the game includes [[platform game]] elements in less action-oriented segments. There are also "junction points" that affect the game's outcome. The game features episodes of an integrated live-action television show, featuring the actors of the characters. The characters interact with the player's choices, displaying the results of the decisions made.
The game originally was envisioned as a sequel to Remedy's previous game, ''[[Alan Wake]]''. The game's focus was shifted to time travel, as Microsoft wanted a new [[intellectual property]] with interactive storytelling. The team consulted scientists while creating the fictional science in this game. While the video game portion was developed internally by Remedy and directed by studio veteran [[Sam Lake]], the TV side of the game was developed by Lifeboat Productions and directed by [[Ben Ketai]]. [[Shawn Ashmore]], [[Aidan Gillen]] and [[Lance Reddick]] portrayed important roles in the game. The game uses a new engine developed by Remedy, the Northlight engine, and a technology called [[Digital Molecular Matter]].
The game was announced in mid-2013 and was set to release in 2015, but its release was delayed to avoid competition with other Xbox One exclusives. It received a positive reception, with critics praising the game's graphics, gameplay, presentation, and story. Critics had mixed opinions regarding the platforming elements, the convergence of video game and television, and the overall quality of the TV show. The [[Windows 10]] version was criticized for its technical issues. ''Quantum Break'' was the best-selling new intellectual property published by Microsoft since the launch of Xbox One.
==Gameplay== ''Quantum Break'' is an [[action-adventure]] video game played from a [[third-person perspective]]. Players play as Jack Joyce, who has time manipulation powers in a world where time stutters, making everything freeze except Joyce.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-12-07-fresh-gameplay-footage-of-xbox-one-exclusive-quantum-break |title=Gameplay footage of Xbox One exclusive Quantum Break |last=Phillips |first=Tom |date=8 December 2013 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=8 December 2013}}</ref> Players face a variety of enemies, including Monarch security guards; Strikers, who are equipped with specially-designed suits which allow them to manipulate time;<ref name ="GRadarPowers">{{cite web|url= http://www.gamesradar.com/all-quantum-breaks-time-powers-explained/ |title=All of Quantum Breaks time powers, explained |first=Joe |last=Skrebels |work=[[GamesRadar]] |date=11 February 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> and Juggernauts, heavily armored enemies equipped with very strong firearms.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/videos/2016/04/06/quantum-break-the-heavily-armored-monarch-juggernaut-is-a-tough-fight |title=Quantum Break: The Heavily Armored Monarch Juggernaut is a Tough Fight |work=[[IGN]] |date=6 April 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> Different enemies have different behaviors, and the game requires players to deploy different tactics and strategies in order to defeat them.<ref name="VentureBeatTips"/>
[[File:Quantum Break gameplay screenshot.jpg |thumb |left |In this screenshot, the [[player character]] is using Time Stop to defeat enemies]] To defeat enemies, players can make use of various offensive and defensive abilities. Jack can find four types of firearms: pistols, assault rifles, shotguns, and carbine rifles.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.primagames.com/games/quantum-break/feature/best-guns-quantum-break |title=The Best Guns in Quantum Break |first=Robert |last=Workman |work=[[Prima Games]] |date=8 April 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> He also possesses several types of time manipulating powers, which increase his efficiency in combat. "Time Stop" freezes time around enemies with a time bubble. If the player shoots an opponent trapped in the bubble, its power amplifies, and the bullets will kill the enemy when the bubble vanishes after a short period of time.<ref name= "GRadarPowers"/> "Time Rush" allows Jack to dash next to an enemy and perform an immediate melee takedown.<ref name="DSpy"/> He can also use this power to speed up time and dodge between cover to confuse unaware enemies as to his location.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.destructoid.com/quantum-break-piqued-my-curiosity-but-it-still-has-a-lot-to-prove-279726.phtml |title=Quantum Break piqued my curiosity, but it still has a lot to prove| first=Brett| last=Makedonski| work=[[Destructoid]]| date=21 August 2015| accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref> "Time Blast" levitates enemies and freezes them.<ref name="VentureBeatTips">{{cite web |url= https://venturebeat.com/2016/04/05/quantum-break-tips-and-tricks-that-will-keep-you-from-getting-stuck-in-time/ |title=Quantum Break tips and tricks that keep you from getting stuck in time |first=Dean |last=Takahashi |work=[[VentureBeat]] |date=5 April 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> The defensive ability "Time Shield" deflects all incoming damage, while "Time Dodge" allows players to dash quickly to evade attacks. Most of these time manipulating powers have a short [[cooldown]] period after use.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/killing-time-in-quantum-break/1100-6434682/ |title=Killing Time in Quantum Break |first=Tamoor |last=Hussain |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=11 February 2016| accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> In combat, Jack automatically takes cover when he is standing next to environmental objects.<ref name="DSpytips">{{cite web|url= http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/xbox-one/feature/a788867/quantum-break-guide-tips-and-tricks-for-taking-on-monarch/ |title=Quantum Break guide: Tips and tricks for taking on Monarch |first=Sam |last=Loveridge |work=[[Digital Spy]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> However, the [[artificial intelligence]] in the game is designed to push the player out of cover by coordinating with each other.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gamesradar.com/quantum-break-secretly-sweet-max-payne-game/| title=Quantum Break is secretly a sweet Max Payne game|first=Joe |last= Skerebels |work=[[GamesRadar]] |date=11 February 2016| accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref>
Jack has other time powers that are not used in combat. "Time Vision" reveals points of interest, and highlights interactive objects and enemies.<ref name="GRadarPowers"/> "Time Echoes" allow him to locate enemies and allies, and replay past events, providing additional information about the story.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://news.xbox.com/2016/04/08/a-deeper-look-at-quantum-breaks-time-shifting-powers/ |title=A Deeper Look at Quantum Break’s Time-Shifting Powers |first=Andrew |last=Fitch |work=Xbox.com |date=8 April 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.pcgamer.com/hands-on-with-quantum-breaks-strange-blend-of-gunplay-and-tv-show/ |title=Hands on with Quantum Break's strange blend of gunplay and TV show |first=Tim |last=Clark |work=[[PC Gamer]] |date=1 March 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> The game features several types of collectibles known as "narrative objects",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.destructoid.com/quantum-break-plays-like-a-dream-345679.phtml|title=Quantum Break plays like a dream|first=Steven|last=Hansen|work=[[Destructoid]]|date=1 March 2016|accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> including quantum ripples, documents, computers, and media. They give players additional insight into the game's story and background. Players can collect "chronon sources", which can be used as [[experience (gaming)|experience point]]s to purchase time power enhancements.<ref name="VentureBeatTips"/>
There are also less action-oriented segments in the game, where players have to solve [[puzzle game|environmental puzzles]], which usually function as a [[Video game graphics|3D]] [[platform game|platformer]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-08-20-is-quantum-break-more-than-a-run-of-the-mill-third-person-shooter |title=Is there more to Quantum Break than run-of-the-mill third-person shooting? |first=Wesley |last=Yin-Poole |work=[[Eurogamer]] |date=20 August 2014 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref> With time stuttering and collapsing, objects may get trapped in a time loop and either become platforms for players to proceed into the next section of the game, or create dangerous environmental hazards, which are extremely unstable.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.vg247.com/2015/08/11/quantum-breaks-action-looks-familiar-but-its-fmv-twist-is-fresh/ |title=Quantum Break’s action looks familiar, but its FMV twist is fresh |first=Alex |last=Donaldson |work=[[VG247]] |date=11 August 2015| accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.videogamer.com/xboxone/quantum_break/preview-3763.html |title=Quantum Break: Gaming's Hollywood action-thriller – Gamescom 2014 |first=John |last=Robertson |work=VideoGamer.com |date=15 August 2014 |accessdate=4 October 2015}}</ref> In the latter case they become obstacles that block the player's path. Jack can overcome them by using his time manipulation powers, such as slowing down or stopping time, so that he can proceed without getting hurt. He can also revive frozen [[non-playable characters]] at several specific points of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://uk.ign.com/articles/2014/08/13/gamescom-2014-quantum-break-looks-fun-to-play-but-will-it-be-fun-to-watch |title=Gamescom 2014: Quantum Break Looks Fun To Play, But Will It Be Fun To Watch? |first=Tristan |last=Oglivie |date=13 August 2014 |accessdate=4 October 2015 |work=[[IGN]]}}</ref>
The gameplay splits into five acts. After playing through an act of the game as Jack Joyce, players take control of the antagonist Paul Serene for a pivotal concurrent decision that impacts the plot, before an episode of the digital show will play. In the game, the video game portion tells the story of the protagonists while the show tells the story of the antagonists. Players can make choices at the beginning of each episode of the TV show, also known as "junction points." These decisions influence the state of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2013/11/22/remedy-s-sam-lake-details-quantum-break-s-transmedia-approach.aspx |title=Remedy’s Sam Lake Details Quantum Break’s Transmedia Approach |first=Mike |last=Futter |work=[[Game Informer]] |date=22 November 2013 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="DSpyadventure">{{cite web|url= http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/feature/a662707/quantum-break-is-part-game-part-live-action-tv-show-part-choose-your-own-adventure.html#~pq8TNpEq0EmqDi |title=Quantum Break is part game, part live-action TV show, part choose your own adventure |first=Matthew |last=Reynolds |work=[[Digital Spy]] |date=15 August 2015 |accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> As Paul Serene has [[precognition|precognitive]] power, players can view the consequences of each choice before making a decision.<ref name="VentureBeatTips"/>
== Synopsis ==
=== Overview === {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | align = right | total_width = 320
| image1 = Shawn Ashmore SDCC 2014.jpg | width1 = 500 | height1 = 700 | caption1 = [[Shawn Ashmore]] plays the story's protagonist, Jack Joyce
| image2 = Aidan Gillen (headshot).jpg | width2 = 500 | height2 = 700 | caption2 = [[Aidan Gillen]] plays the story's antagonist, Paul Serene
}}
''Quantum Break'' is set at and around Riverport, where, due to miscalculations by Paul Serene, a [[time travel]] experiment goes wrong.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/6/13/4427698/quantum-break-xbox-one |title=Quantum Break Brings Binge Viewing To Video Games |last=Plante |first=Chris |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=13 June 2013 |accessdate=21 June 2013}}</ref> Doused in chronon radiation, the material that makes time travel possible, Jack Joyce and Paul Serene are granted time-based abilities; for example, both can freeze time and move at higher speeds, whilst a higher dose of chronons means Serene can [[Precognition|see into the future]] to decide which choices to make in the present.<ref name="wondering">{{cite web |url=http://kotaku.com/quantum-breaks-creator-says-its-tv-game-hybrid-makes-p-512948212 |title=If You're Wondering What The Hell Quantum Break Is, Here You Go |last=Amini |first=Tina |work=[[Kotaku]] |date=12 June 2013 |accessdate=21 June 2013}}</ref> Additionally, the collapse of the machine damages the structure of time, causing a "fracture" that sporadically freezes the passage of time for all without time-travel abilities or the correct equipment. Joyce and his ally, Beth Wilder, are subsequently pursued by Monarch Solutions, a corporation founded by Serene.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://remedygames.com/quantum-break-e3-trailer/?_ga=1.11838388.1246741597.1427452777|title = Quantum Break E3 trailer|date = 10 June 2013|accessdate = 4 August 2015|website = [[Remedy Games]]|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117014932/http://remedygames.com/quantum-break-e3-trailer/?_ga=1.11838388.1246741597.1427452777|archivedate = 17 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
The rules of the story stress that time cannot be changed through traveller actions as per the [[Novikov self-consistency principle]]; Paul Serene gives an example of trying to save a dead vagrant he and Jack discovered in their youth, only to startle the vagrant and cause the fall that killed him when he goes back in time. Another enforced rule is that travelers can only move between machines located at different times using the same core: as such, it is impossible for the characters to travel back before the first power-up of the core, nor would they be able to travel between different time machines as the cores would be different. The game features narration from Jack himself.<ref name="VG" />
=== Plot === {{See also|List of Quantum Break episodes}} Agreeing to help his best friend Paul Serene with a demonstration, Jack Joyce learns that Paul has been expanding on the physics work of Jack's estranged brother, William, and has built a time machine that works using "chronon particles." Paul activates the machine, only for it to jam shut and break as William appears. Will demands Jack and Paul stop their actions, else "time will break." The machine becomes unstable and douses Jack and Paul in chronon radiation that gives them time-based powers. Monarch Solutions soldiers appear and steal the time machine's core, Jack and Will meet an older Paul. Claiming to have seen the "End of Time", this Paul refuses Will's suggestions of fixing the fracture, claiming time cannot be changed. Paul has the building detonated, causing Will to be seemingly killed by falling debris. Jack is knocked unconscious and captured by Monarch.
Escaping Monarch during a time stutter, Jack rescues either Nick or Amy, students apprehended by Monarch who agree to help him. Working off a clue with Beth Wilder, a friend of Will's working as double agent inside Monarch, Jack heads to the abandoned Bradbury Swimming Pool, where he finds that Will has built his own time machine and a counter-measure to fix the fracture, called the Chronon Field Regulator (CFR), but the time machine is inoperable. Jack suggests they kidnap Dr. Sofia Amaral, Paul's head of chronon research. Learning she will be attending a Monarch gala, Jack surrenders to Monarch and learns that Paul was accidentally sent to the end of time in the future, only escaping by traveling in Will's machine back to its first activation in 1999. Escaping through the Monarch Labs, Jack and Beth pull Amaral out of the path of a hacked drone before it explodes. Beth escapes by the sea with Amaral while Jack steals Paul's car.
Paul revealed to be dying from "chronon syndrome,"{{efn|Caused by overexposure to chronon radiation, the illness is detrimental to his health and incurable and requires medical chronon exposure, similarly to real-life [[radiotherapy]]. The disease is implied to be what allows him to see possible futures, unlike Jack.}} lashes out at his second-in-command Martin Hatch, as Amaral was the only one capable of administering his treatment. Now paranoid, Paul places all of his trust in either Amaral or Hatch, who claims that Amaral left willingly with Jack. Paul recognizes Beth from security footage— she was also at the end of time and attempted to kill Serene.
Taking Amaral to the Bradbury Pool, Jack and Beth force her to help repair the time machine. With Will's documents noting that the CFR disappeared in 2010, Jack and Beth plot to head to 2010 and steal it, closing a [[causal loop]]. Beth steps into the machine as Amaral sabotages the computer and alerts Monarch. Leaving Amaral with Nick/Amy, Jack heads to 2010 and finds Beth, much older and disturbed. Beth explains that Amaral sent her to the end of time, where she met the younger Paul. Failing to kill him, Beth followed him back to the first activation in 1999 and stopped him from murdering Will. After directing Will to create the CFR, she has waited eleven years for Jack to arrive in 2010.
Beth and Jack reach Will's workshop and find the CFR, but Paul corners Beth and shoots her when she refuses to co-operate. The CFR is accidentally activated, causing a chronon burst; the exposure throws Jack forward to 2016 again and causes Paul's chronon syndrome. Beth shuts off the CFR but is executed by Paul while Jack can only watch through time.
Increasingly paranoid and ill, Paul is informed that, despite his lab being destroyed by Hatch, one damaged treatment has been recovered. Paul either decides to take it and buy time for himself and his plan or succumb to paranoia and illness. As stutters become nearly constant, Jack fights through the Monarch HQ with the guidance of either head of surveillance Charlie Wincott or Wincott's close friend Fiona Miller. Reaching Paul's lab, Jack finds either Wincott or high-level Monarch security officer Liam Burke, who is intent on stopping him. Acquiring the CFR, Jack learns that Paul was using it to power a "lifeboat," a small bunker where researchers could devise a solution to the end of time while protected from it. Unable to work the CFR, Jack uses Monarch's time machine (equipped with the stolen university core) to travel back to its first activation: the night of Will's death.
Rushing through the University, Jack narrowly rescues Will from the falling debris. Will warns Jack he cannot simply repair the fracture then and there, as it would erase key future events and risk a [[time paradox]]. Passing a frozen Beth during a stutter, Jack reaches to unfreeze her but hesitates and leaves. Reaching the Bradbury Pool, Jack and Will travel forward in time, only to find Paul and Monarch waiting for them. Paul is intent on either retrieving the CFR or destroying it. Jack fights and kills him. Hooking the CFR into his time machine, Will asks Jack to [[jump start (vehicle)|jumpstart]] it with chronon energy. The CFR activates and blasts the area with chronons, fixing the tear and vaporizing Paul. As Will examines the CFR, burnt out from the blast, Jack has a vision of his future self-traveling to the end of time and begins exhibiting symptoms of chronon syndrome.
In a flash-forward, Jack is shown approaching the frozen Beth back at the University, whispering that he'll come back for her. An epilogue shows Jack leaving an interview and being approached by Hatch,{{efn|Despite Hatch's death being shown in Episode 4, additional collectibles and a [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]] imply that Hatch is a shifter capable of self-control and living in spaces with time.}} who explains everything has been simply blamed on Paul, and offers Jack a place at the renewed Monarch; Jack is shown seeing a split pathway similarly to Paul, ending before he makes a decision.<ref name="VG">{{cite video game |title=Quantum Break |developer=[[Remedy Entertainment]] |publisher=[[Microsoft Studios]] |date=5 April 2016 |platform=[[Xbox One]] |version=1.0 }}</ref>
=== Cast === {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center | align = right | total_width = 320 | image1 = Lance Reddick portrait 2009.jpg | width1 = 500 | height1 = 700 | caption1= [[Lance Reddick]] plays Martin Hatch
| image2 = Dominic Monaghan 2009 cropped.jpg | width2 = 500 | height2 = 700 | caption2 = [[Dominic Monaghan]] plays William Joyce }} The game's cast of actors was revealed at [[Gamescom]] 2015.<ref>{{cite web |date=4 August 2015 |url=http://news.xbox.com/2015/08/gamescom-quantum-break |title=gamescom 2015: Quantum Break Announces an All-star Cast |publisher=Xbox Wire |accessdate=4 August 2015}}</ref> * [[Shawn Ashmore]] as Jack Joyce * [[Aidan Gillen]] as Paul Serene, Jack's former best friend, the mastermind behind Monarch Solutions and secondary player character. * [[Patrick Heusinger]] as Liam Burke, one of Monarch's lead security staff, central character to the episodes, and recurring game character. * [[Marshall Allman]] as Charlie Wincott, Monarch's head of surveillance and central character to the episodes. * Courtney Hope as Beth Wilder, a Monarch [[double agent]] whom Will trusts and Jack befriends. * [[Mimi Michaels]] as Fiona Miller, a Monarch employee and close friend of Charlie Wincott, and central character to the episodes. * [[Brooke Nevin]] as Emily Burke, Liam Burke's pregnant wife and a recurring show character. * Jacqueline Piñol as Dr. Sofia Amaral, one of Serene's advisers who acts as his doctor. * [[Amelia Rose Blaire]] as Amy Ferrero, the lead protester who, depending on Serene's actions, is either a supporting character or is killed following the first act. * Sean Durrie as Nick Marsters, the taxi driver from the introduction. Should Amy die due to Serene's choices, Nick fills her supporting role in the story. * [[Lance Reddick]] as Martin Hatch, Serene's second-in-command who acts as the [[CEO]] and face of Monarch. * [[Dominic Monaghan]] as William Joyce, Jack's estranged brother and physicist. * Jeannie Bolet (mocap/looks) and [[Jules de Jongh]] (voice) as Commander Clarice Ogawa
==Development==
===Origin=== [[File:Sam Lake-MichaelFörtsch.jpg|thumb|150px|right|''Quantum Break'' is directed by [[Sam Lake]].]] ''Quantum Break'' was developed by Finnish developer [[Remedy Entertainment]] and published by [[Microsoft Studios]]. In 2010, the company released ''[[Alan Wake]]'', another title published by Microsoft. The game received high critical praise but was not a significant commercial success for either company. Remedy intended to develop a sequel to ''Alan Wake'' after the release of the first game, and hoped to include live action elements into the game. The concept was pitched to Microsoft, who showed no interest in publishing another ''Alan Wake'' game and wanted to diversify their games lineup.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.polygon.com/features/2015/4/20/8450329/alan-wake-2-prototype-video-interview |title=Introducing The Alan Wake 2 You Will Never Play |first=Brian |last=Crecente |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=20 April 2015 |accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
However, Microsoft was impressed by the idea of having a live action show within a video game, wanted to publish a game featuring interactive narrative. They hoped to partner with Remedy for a new [[intellectual property]], in which Remedy could expand the live action part of the game; Remedy agreed.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-03-07-remedy-is-still-in-talks-about-alan-wake-2| title=Remedy still in talks about Alan Wake 2 |first=Martin |last=Robinson |work=[[Eurogamer]] |date=7 March 2016| accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> The team believed that one of the best themes that can accommodate a story with choices was [[time travel]], as the general idea of this kind of story is to change past events. The idea of having a game about quantum physics originated from ''Alan Wake''{{'}}s additional TV show called "Quantum Suicide".<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2015/11/16/new-gameplay-and-insight-into-quantum-breaks-origins.aspx| title=Microsoft's Long Game: Inside Quantum Break's Challenging Development| first=Ben| last=Hanson| work=[[Game Informer]]| date=16 November 2015| accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/on-building-dueling-narratives-in-quantum-break/1100-6435197/ |title=On Building Dueling Narratives in Quantum Break |first=Alexa |last=Ray Corriea |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=1 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> After settling on the genre, the team pitched the project to Microsoft again and was accepted.<ref name="PolyFeature">{{cite web|url= http://www.polygon.com/2015/8/6/9107169/quantum-break-details-gamescom-xbox-one-remedy-sam-lake |title=How you'll play and watch Quantum Break (and why you shouldn't skip the cutscenes) |first=Dave |last=Tach |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=6 August 2015 |accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> The game was directed by [[Sam Lake]], the writer of ''Alan Wake'' and Remedy's previous games, ''[[Max Payne (video game)|Max Payne]]'' and ''[[Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne]]''. Greg Louden, who received an [[Academy Award for Visual Effects]] for his work in ''[[Gravity (film)|Gravity]]'', served as a narrative designer.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2014/03/05/remedy-s-greg-louden-discusses-his-work-on-gravity-and-quantum-break.aspx |title=Remedy’s Greg Louden Discusses His Work On Gravity And Quantum Break |first=Mike |last=Futter |work=[[Game Informer]] |date=5 March 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> [[Ben Ketai]] was the TV show's director.<ref name="show director"/> Pre-production of the game began in 2011; approximately 100 people worked on the game.<ref name="Complicated story">{{cite web|url= https://venturebeat.com/2016/03/01/how-remedy-kept-control-of-a-very-complicated-story-across-the-quantum-break-games-and-video-episodes/ |title=How Remedy controlled a complicated story across the Quantum Break games and videos |first=Dean |last=Takahashi |work=[[VentureBeat]] |date=1 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
===Story=== {{quotebox|quote= "We really consciously wanted to take our learnings from the previous games and push the idea of what makes a good Remedy game forward. Take all the storytelling lessons from ''Alan Wake'', take the cinematic action lessons from ''Max Payne'', and combine it all into one game." |width=33% |source = — [[Sam Lake]], creative director of the game.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.standard.co.uk/stayingin/tech-gaming/quantum-break-interview-sam-lake-on-storytelling-scifi-blockbusters-and-why-it-s-the-ultimate-remedy-a3215536.html |title=Quantum Break interview: Sam Lake on storytelling, sci-fi blockbusters, and why it’s ‘the ultimate Remedy game’ |first=Ben |last=Travis |work=[[Standard.co.uk]] |date=March 31, 2016 |accessdate=June 30, 2016}}</ref>}}
The game's story was written by a team of three full-time writers along with Lake, with a goal of making it "believable". As a result, the team drew numerous inspirations from [[popular culture|pop culture]] and included various references to films like ''[[Inception]]'' and ''[[Interstellar (film)|Interstellar]]''. The team was also inspired by ''[[The Matrix]]'', ''[[The Terminator]]'', ''[[Back to the Future]]'', ''[[Primer (film)|Primer]]'', ''[[Looper (film)|Looper]]'', and other films.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2015/11/18/remedy-s-favorite-tv-shows-and-the-time-travel-movies-influencing-quantum-break.aspx?PostPageIndex=2 |title=Remedy’s Top TV Shows And The Time-Travel Movies Influencing Quantum Break |first=Kyle |last=Hilliard| work=[[Game Informer]] |date=18 November 2015 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> The game's story was described as "complicated", and Louden had to create a chart for the team to keep track of the story progression.<ref name="Complicated story"/> Lake described the game as Remedy's most ambitious project and the "ultimate Remedy game", since the team learnt from ''Alan Wake'' and attempted to refine the formula. As in ''Alan Wake'', the game's theme revolves around family. Lake also drew inspiration from the pacing and plot twists of TV shows, and hoped that the game's story would be unpredictable.<ref name="GSpot TPS">{{cite web| url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/quantum-break-interview-its-the-most-ambitious-gam/1100-6434705/ |title=Quantum Break Interview: "It’s The Most Ambitious Game We’ve Worked On" |first=Tamoor |last=Hussain |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=12 February 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> He also reinterpreted familiar film [[cliché]]s in an attempt to make dated ideas fresh again.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/04/a-remedy-for-cliches-sam-lake-on-quantum-break.html |title=A Remedy for Clichés: Sam Lake on Quantum Break |first=Cameron |last=Kunzelman |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016 |work=[[Paste Magazine]]}}</ref> To add dimensions, the team took inspirations from postmodern literature and included many self-references, such as a standalone TV show called ''Alan Wake's Return''.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.pcgamer.com/sam-lake-quantum-break-alan-wake-max-payne-interview/ |title=Sam Lake on Quantum Break and what's next for Alan Wake |first=Tyler |last=Wilde |work=[[PC Gamer]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
The game's "junction point" concept was created by Louden. There are approximately 40 variations in the game TV show, triggered by "quantum ripples", which unlock deleted scenes and give players additional insight on the story, and junction points. The player plays part of the game as Paul Serene and makes decisions as him at these points. Inspired by ''[[Die Hard]]'', the writers hoped that this approach would allow them to create a complex villain with depth.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2013/11/22/remedy-s-sam-lake-details-quantum-break-s-transmedia-approach.aspx |title=Remedy’s Sam Lake Details Quantum Break’s Transmedia Approach |first=Mike |last=Futter |work=[[Game Informer]] |date=22 November 2013| accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> According to Louden, the story characters are not "black and white", and depending on the player's perspective, players will feel sympathy for the villain and feel torn when making the choices. Junction points were a tool used by Remedy to add replayability to the game, unlocking alternate content and changing the state of the world,<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.shacknews.com/article/93637/quantum-break-narrative-designer-discusses-junction-points-time-powers-and-episodic-gaming |title=Quantum Break narrative designer discusses Junction points, time powers, and episodic gaming |first=Ozzie |last=Mejia |work=[[Shacknews]] |date=8 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> and the gameplay segments remain identical regardless of players' choices.<ref name="Complicated story"/>
''Quantum Break'' was described as a "transmedia action-shooter video game and television hybrid".<ref name="feature"/> At its core the game is an [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] game with a live action TV show bundled with it. According to Lake, the product was designed to be a complete package, players are encouraged to both play the game and watch the show. While the game allows players to skip the TV show completely, Remedy advise against such behaviors, as players may miss crucial details if they do not watch the show. The game features many collectibles, which serve a narrative purpose. Lake explained that once players find a collectible, they will trigger a [[butterfly effect]], whose consequences will be shown during the show. The show also shows some objects, which can be found in the core game. Through this approach, the team hoped that they could offer an experience that is unique and personalized for all players, and increase the depth of the story.<ref name="PolyFeature"/> Initially, the game and the TV show were to tell drastically different stories featuring a completely different set of characters. However, Lake eventually scrapped the idea, and the game and the show echo each other more closely.<ref name="venturebeat">{{cite web|url= https://venturebeat.com/2016/04/11/remedys-sam-lake-stepped-up-the-creativity-and-ambition-with-microsofts-quantum-break/ |title=How Remedy’s Sam Lake stepped up the ambition and creativity of Quantum Break | first=Dean| last=Takahashi |work=[[VentureBeat]] |date=11 April 2016 |accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> Lake described the TV show as a "natural progression" for the studio, having experimented with the format with the two ''Max Payne'' games, which feature televisions, and ''Alan Wake'', which has the ''Bright Falls'' live action show,<ref name="NL"/> and ''[[Alan Wake: American Nightmare]]'', which features live-action cutscenes.<ref name="venturebeat"/> Producer Thomas Puha added that the game is "the culmination of 21 years of work".<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.vg247.com/2016/03/04/quantum-break-gameplay/ |title=Quantum Break is "the culmination of 21 years of work" |first=Danny |last=Wadeson |work=[[VG247]] |date=4 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Lake added that the TV part can serve as an entry point for people who do not play video games frequently, and draw them into video gaming.<ref name="feature"/> To keep both parts consistent, the team also consulted a filmmaker who gave them advice regarding the game's camera styles and depth of field to allow smooth transitions between the two mediums.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.polygon.com/2014/8/12/5991679/quantum-break-remedy-entertainment-cinematic-director |title=A filmmaker is helping to make Quantum Break the most cinematic game Remedy has ever made |first=Emily |last=Gera |date=12 August 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2016 |work= [[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]}}</ref>
Lake initially thought Microsoft was not particularly enthusiastic about the idea, but had accepted the pitch mainly because of Microsoft's vision of having Xbox One as an entertainment device with rich TV features at that time.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/remedy-s-quantum-leap-sam-lake-on-the-studio-s-most-ambitious-game-yet/0164881 |title=Remedy's Quantum leap: Sam Lake talks about the studio's most ambitious game yet |first=Alex |last=Calvin |work=[[Market for Home Computing and Video Games]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> However, as the TV show was not part of Microsoft's project, the closure of [[Xbox Entertainment Studios]] did not affect the progress of the TV show production.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.engadget.com/2014/07/18/quantum-break-not-impacted-by-xbox-entertainment-studios-closure/ |title=Quantum Break not impacted by Xbox Entertainment Studios closure| first=Sinan| last=Kubba| work=[[Engadget]]| date=18 July 2014| accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> It was created by Lifeboat Productions, who worked closely with Remedy through [[Skype]] conversation and screenplay review. Many scenes had to be shot twice due to the game's alternate content and branching nature. Three writers from Remedy also contributed to the TV show content.<ref name="Complicated story"/>
With Microsoft's funding, Remedy hired lots of high-profile actors, including [[Shawn Ashmore]], [[Aidan Gillen]], [[Lance Reddick]] and [[Dominic Monaghan]]. During the game's announcement and first gameplay reveal at [[Gamescom 2014]], Jack Joyce was portrayed by Shaun Derry. According to Louden, they were creating the animation for Ashmore's character, and did not have sufficient time to finalize them before the event, so they used their game prototype, which has Derry starring as the lead character, as the game's demo. The change in lead actors also prompted the studio to update and change the game cover art.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2015/08/15/quantum-break-gets-box-art-redesign |title=New Quantum Break Box Art Revealed |first=Alex |last=Osborn |work=[[IGN]] |date=15 August 2015 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Ashmore, Monaghan and Gillen were announced as the game's protagonists and antagonists a year later, and Derry starred in the game as Nick.<ref name="venturebeat"/>
===Design=== While developing the game, Remedy consulted Syksy Räsänen, a scientist who is a lecturer at [[Helsinki University]] and had worked at [[CERN]]. She taught them how to write the plot in such a way that it adhered to current [[theoretical physics]] and [[quantum physics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/quantum-break-interview-sam-lake|title=How real physics impacted time-travel game Quantum Break|work=[[Wired.co.uk]]|date=30 March 2016|accessdate=30 June 2016|first=Matt|last=Kamen}}</ref> The development team held several brainstorming sessions, which inspired the team and helped them to fix the design of the game's time machine. The team was also inspired, when creating their own fictional "Meyer-Joyce particle" and "Meyer-Joyce field", by the [[Higgs boson]] and Higgs fields.<ref name="venturebeat"/>
According to Lake, they experimented with different gameplay mechanics, some of which they judged to make the game too slow or too tactical. They intended to "recapture the action spectacle" featured in their ''[[Max Payne (video game)|Max Payne]]'' series, along with several modern iterations.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://metro.co.uk/2016/03/09/quantum-break-hands-on-preview-and-interview-we-wanted-to-recapture-the-action-spectacle-we-had-with-max-payne-5741405/ |title=Quantum Break hands-on preview and interview – ‘we wanted to recapture the action spectacle we had with Max Payne’ |first=David |last=Jenkins |work=[[Metro (magazine)|Metro]] |date=9 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> The game was designed to be fast-paced, but the concept of time-travel did not accommodate the elements of this kind of gameplay. As a result, the team opted to include a broader theme: time itself. They set the game in a world where time collapses, leading to various dangerous situations. According to Lake, the theme of time connected all the elements featured in the game. The setting also allowed the team to add new gameplay mechanics, such as the time manipulation powers.<ref name="venturebeat"/> They created ''Quantum Break'' as a [[third-person shooter]] because of their past experiences with the genre and because they thought that the third-person perspective would allow them to show a strong leading character, while a purely story-oriented game would not feel like a [[AAA (video game industry)|triple A]] title.<ref name="GSpot TPS"/>
Louden says the team put a lot of work into the game's difficulty. They hoped that the time powers would let the player feel like a [[superhero]], while still allowing for challenging moments.<ref name="Complicated story"/> Learning from criticism of ''Alan Wake'', they introduced several puzzles in order to increase variety and change the pace.<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/gaming/what-to-play/quantum-break-interview-pc-release-date-and-new-trailer/ |title=Quantum Break interview, PC release date and new trailer |first=Tom |last=Hoggins |work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |date= 11 February 2015 |accessdate= 30 June 2016}}</ref> The puzzles also serve to remind players of their arsenal of abilities. Some of the environmental puzzles, including the rewind feature, were inspired by titles like ''[[Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time]]'' and ''[[Life Is Strange]]'', while the stutter sequences were inspired by ''[[Salvador Dali (film)|Salvador Dali]]'' and ''Inception'''s dream sequence.<ref name="Complicated story"/>
When time stutters occur, the game's visual changes to inform players that they will encounter new enemies and obstacles. The levels in the game were designed to feature open environments to allow players to use the time manipulation powers freely and encouraging them to explore. Kyle Rowley, lead designer of the game, described them as "arenas". The stutters were also designed to convey stories: Players can inspect the [[non-playable character]]s stuck in a time stutter and learn about what happened to them when time freezes. To prevent the game from relying excessively on its cover system, the [[artificial intelligence]] (AI) of the game was designed to attack the player aggressively in order to drive the player out from cover. Time powers affect AI behaviors, and Remedy built a new system that allows the AI to search for the player character after Time Rush is used.<ref name="level design">{{cite web|url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/how-quantum-breaks-developers-tackled-time-manipul/1100-6436820/ |title=How Quantum Break's Developers Tackled Time Manipulation Combat |first=Justin |last=Haywald |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=3 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
===Technology=== The game utilizes a new in-house engine called the Northlight Engine.<ref name="NL">{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/games/quantum_break/b/xboxone/archive/2013/06/21/remedy-s-sam-lake-talks-quantum-break-and-alan-wake-2.aspx|title=Remedy’s Sam Lake Talks Quantum Break And Alan Wake 2|first=Tim|last=Turi|work=[[Game Informer]]|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> To represent the idea of "broken time" and have a detailed destruction system, the team created lots of environments which put the player character in the midst of destruction, utilizing technologies ranging from geometric distortion waves to Thinking Particles.<ref name="tech">{{cite web|url=https://www.fxguide.com/featured/time-for-destruction-the-tech-of-quantum-break/|title=Time for destruction: the tech of Quantum Break|first=Ian|last=Failes|work=FX Guide|date=21 April 2016|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> The team also used [[Digital Molecular Matter]], a technology developed by Pixelux that allows structures and objects to react in the game the same way they would in reality. According to Mikko Uromo, the technology allows them to "simulate complex scenarios on a scale that hasn't been possible before" and is crucial to the game's development.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.videogamer.com/xboxone/quantum_break/news/quantum_break_gets_advanced_digital_molecular_matter_destruction_tech.html |title=Quantum Break gets advanced 'Digital Molecular Matter' destruction tech |first=David |last=Scammell |work=VideoGamer.com |date=25 November 2013 |accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref> The team also worked significantly on the game's lighting system. It was designed to be dynamic, and the team refined it to include eyes and hair. They also created a new [[global illumination]] system for indirect lighting.<ref name="tech"/> The game's [[Display resolution|resolution]] foundation was [[720p]], but Remedy attempted to raise it to [[1080p]] by using [[3D reconstruction|temporal reconstruction]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/quantum-breaks-resolution-is-a-complicated-issue-s/1100-6435898/ |title=Quantum Break's Resolution Is a Complicated Issue, Says Dev |first=Tamoor |last=Hussain |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=22 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
The team spent a lot of resources in carrying out detailed [[motion capture]], to enhance players' engagement with the story and make it easier for them to form emotional attachments to characters, and to keep the game and the TV show consistent with each other. They also hoped that use of this technology would add realism to the game and prevent players from getting distracted by the characters' unrealistic behaviors and appearances.<ref name="feature">{{cite web |url= http://www.polygon.com/2013/6/13/4427698/quantum-break-xbox-one |title=Quantum Break Brings Binge Viewing To Video Games |first=Chris |last=Plante |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=13 June 2013 |accessdate=26 June 2016}}</ref> Lake added that one of the challenges when recording motion capture is to convince the inexperienced actors, who thought that the system lacked complexity, not to overact. According to Lake, the game features a technology that creates realistic digital counterparts of the characters and records every little detail of their faces.<ref name="NL"/> The team initially did the recording at [[Los Angeles]], where actors need to wear spandex suits with tracking marks and head cameras. Remedy invited the actors to Remedy's office in [[Helsinki]], where they used their own technology to carry out extremely detailed motion capturing of facial expressions and movements in dialogue. Ashmore described the chamber for motion capturing as a "Sweat Box", as actors must remain steady, moving only their faces, in order to prevent the motion capture data from getting ruined.<ref>{{cite interview |last=Ashmore |first=Shawn |subject= |subject-link= Shawn Ashmore |interviewer= Matthew Jarvis |title=Quantum Break actor details Remedy's 'Sweat Box' method for photorealistic facial capture |url= http://www.develop-online.net/news/quantum-break-actor-details-remedy-s-sweat-box-method-for-photorealistic-facial-capture/0219650 |format= |date= 26 April 2016 |access-date=30 June 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160427114012/http://www.develop-online.net/news/quantum-break-actor-details-remedy-s-sweat-box-method-for-photorealistic-facial-capture/0219650 |archive-date=27 April 2016 |dead-url=no |quote= It’s this tiny little room with nine cameras and it captures your facial performance to an almost photo-real level. It’s really, really detailed but part of that is you cannot move, at all... If you move during a take the data is ruined. As you can imagine the game is highly action-oriented, and very emotional – there’s a lot of emotion and yelling and screaming and breaking down, for all the characters for various different reasons.}}</ref>
===Audio=== According to Remedy, audio drives the visual effects. The development team put a lot of effort into differentiating normal time and time stutters. When time enters a stutter, many audio effects change, with guns firing at a lower pitch, while dialogue and music began stretching.<ref name="level design"/> The goal for the change was to allow players to recognize the change of time state "with their eyes shut". The team wrote a reference guide, describing the sound of time stutters. They chose words including "violent" and "unpredictable", but avoided using "sci-fi" and "digital". The team also used [[Audiokinetic Wwise]] to sync audio with gameplay.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.develop-online.net/interview/heard-about-quantum-break/0218665 |title=Heard About: Quantum Break |first=John |last=Broomhall |work=[[Develop (magazine)|Develop]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
The game's soundtrack was composed by Petri Alanko, the composer of ''Alan Wake''. Alanko made use of the modular audio software [[Reaktor]], but was not satisfied with the software's built-in instruments and decided to create his own set of custom sounds. The music in the game was described by Alanko as "meandering" and "sublime" to support the game's emotional moments, while intentionally avoiding aggressive tones.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/272143/Making_waves_The_organic_process_of_creating_Quantum_Breaks_score.php |title= Making waves: The organic process of creating Quantum Break's score |first=Chris |last=Kerr |work=[[Gamasutra]] |date=9 May 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> The soundtrack was inspired by albums from [[Tangerine Dream]], [[Hecq]], [[Michael Stearns]] and [[Aphex Twin]], and Reznorian. He intended to add [[orchestra]]l soundtrack into the game, but Microsoft rejected the idea. The music changed to an [[electronic music|electronic]] style, and he used artificial instruments such as [[Roland Corporation|Roland]] synthesizers.<ref>{{YouTube |6iXK45viIuo |Petri Alanko on composing for Quantum Break with Roland AIRA System-1M}}, promotional video taken from the official Roland YouTube channel, accessed 9 April 2016.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/listen-to-quantum-breaks-soundtrack-early/1100-6435775/ |title=Listen to Quantum Break's Soundtrack Early |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=18 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> [[iam8bit]] is set to release a [[Gramophone record|vinyl]] limited edition of the game's soundtrack in the third quarter of 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/04/05/quantum-break-soundtrack-coming-to-vinyl |title=Quantum Break Soundtrack Coming To Vinyl |first=Luke |last=Reilly |work=[[IGN]]| date=5 April 2016| accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
In 2015 Lifeboat Productions hired [[John Kaefer]] for the soundtrack of the TV show. Kaefer and Alanko did not cooperate with each other closely as the level of interactivity between the two mediums are different. Due to the game's alternate content, he had to compose several music pieces for some scenes. As the TV show served to expand on the story and provide explanation, the music reflects the "ideas of intrigue, deception, tension, love, and loss".<ref name="show director">{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/quantum-break-tv-show-composer-talks-about-working/1100-6438668/ |title=Quantum Break TV Show Composer Talks About Working on His First Game |first=Eddie |last=Makuch |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=9 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
As Remedy encouraged [[YouTubers]] to make videos about the game and players to share their experience with others, the team introduced an audio option which allows players to turn off licensed music. This allows YouTubers to upload their videos online without having to worry about [[copyright infringement]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/269409/Remedy_listens_to_YouTubers_makes_Quantum_Breaks_licensed_jams_optional.php |title=Remedy listens to YouTubers, makes Quantum Break's licensed jams optional |first=Alex |last=Wawro |work=[[Gamasutra]] |date=31 March 2013 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> The licensed music featured in the game was specially chosen by Lake, and is played at the end of each act and the credits scene.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.engadget.com/2016/03/29/quantum-break-stream-safe-music/ |title='Quantum Break' has an audio setting just for streamers |first=Timothy J. |last=Seppala |work=[[Joystiq]] |date=29 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
==Release== ''Quantum Break'' was announced on 21 May 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/05/21/remedy-announces-new-title-quantum-break |title=Remedy Announces Quantum Break |first=Anthony |last=Gallegos |work=[[IGN]] |date=21 May 2013 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Gameplay trailers were released at major conventions, including [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2013]],<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2013/06/18/e3-2013-quantum-break-gives-you-control-of-games-and-tv |title=E3 2013: Quantum Break Gives You Control of Games And TV |first=Mitch |last=Dyer |work=[[IGN]] |date=18 June 2013 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> and [[Spike Video Game Awards|VGX]] Awards 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.videogamer.com/xboxone/quantum_break/news/quantum_break_gameplay_trailer_revealed_at_vgx.html |title=Quantum Break gameplay trailer revealed at VGX |first=David |last=Scammell |work=VideoGamer.com |date=30 June 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Remedy released the first gameplay demo at Microsoft's conference at [[Gamescom 2014]], with Lake saying that the demo would make viewers "speechless".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/xbox-one-exclusive-quantum-break-will-leave-you-sp/1100-6421562/ |title=Xbox One-Exclusive Quantum Break Will "Leave You Speechless" |first=Eddie |last=Makuch |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=7 August 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> The game was originally set for release in 2015, but Microsoft held it to 2016 to avoid competition with other Xbox One exclusives including ''[[Halo 5: Guardians]]'', ''[[Rise of the Tomb Raider]]'', and ''[[Forza Motorsport 6]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url= https://venturebeat.com/2015/04/02/quantum-break-delayed-to-2016-to-ease-xbox-ones-crowded-holiday/ |title=Quantum Break delayed to 2016 to ease Xbox One’s crowded holiday |first=Mike |last=Minotti |work=[[VentureBeat]] |date=2 April 2015| accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> incidentally giving Remedy more time to refine the game.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/how-quantum-break-benefited-from-delay/1100-6436228/ |title=How Quantum Break Benefited From Delay |first=Mat |last=Paget |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> At Gamescom 2016, Microsoft announced that the title would be released on 6 April 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamezone.com/news/xbox-one-exclusive-quantum-break-release-date-announced-3422657 |title=Xbox One exclusive Quantum Break release date announced |first=Mike |last=Boccher |work=GameZone |date=4 August 2015 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> The show was released separately and was not available in the game's retail edition in an effort to save disc space. As a result, both Xbox One and Windows 10 users need to stream the show.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gameinformer.com/b/news/archive/2016/03/01/quantum-break-live-action-scenes-streamed.aspx |title=Quantum Break's Live-Action Episodes Are Streamed To Save Hard Drive And Disc Space |first=Brian |last=Shea |work=[[Game Informer]] |date=1 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Microsoft initially considered other options, including releasing it as a standalone show or a separate [[Xbox Live]] download.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://venturebeat.com/2016/03/01/microsofts-gaming-chief-explains-why-quantum-break-will-be-cool-and-windows-gaming-is-good-for-the-xbox-one/ |title=Microsoft’s gaming chief discusses Quantum Break and why Windows gaming is good for Xbox One |first=Dean |last=Takahashi |work=[[VentureBeat]] |date=1 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
Though ''Quantum Break'' was originally announced as a Xbox One exclusive, Microsoft announced in February 2016 that the game would be released for [[Windows 10]] ([[Universal Windows Platform]]) as well, to launch simultaneously with the Xbox One version. Developed internally by Remedy, the PC version would only be released on [[Windows Store]] and would require [[DirectX 12]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2016/02/microsoft-needs-to-stop-forcing-console-like-restrictions-on-windows-store-pc-games/ |title=Microsoft needs to stop forcing console-like restrictions on Windows Store PC games |last=Walton |first=Mark |work=[[Ars Technica]] |date=29 February 2016 |accessdate=2 March 2016}}</ref> This created a backlash among players, who criticized Microsoft for misleading them into buying a Xbox One by not revealing the PC version's existence when the game was announced. Microsoft's [[Phil Spencer (business executive)|Phil Spencer]] replied by saying that delivering a game to a broader audience "a good thing" and that it could increase the game's sales.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-02-12-not-everyones-thrilled-with-microsofts-quantum-break-pc-announcement |title=Not everyone's thrilled with Microsoft's Quantum Break PC announcement |first=Wesley |last=Yin-Poole |work=[[Eurogamer]] |date=12 February 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Lake added that he was "confused" and "baffled" by the responses of the community.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mcvuk.com/news/read/remedy-baffled-by-fanboy-fury-over-quantum-break-pc-release/0164875 |title=Remedy 'baffled' by fanboy fury over Quantum Break PC release |first=Alex |last=Calvin |work=[[Market for Home Computing and Video Games]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-03-04-i-was-slightly-confused-by-the-reaction |title="I was slightly confused by the reaction" |first=Martin |last=Robinson |work=[[Eurogamer]] |date=4 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref>
Players who purchase the Xbox One version of the game would receive a digital code for the Windows 10 version. ''Alan Wake'', along with its two [[downloadable content|downloadable]] special episodes "The Signal" and "The Writer", as well as ''American Nightmare'', would be available for free for players who purchased the game through [[backward compatibility]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-02-11-quantum-break-is-coming-to-pc-too|title=Quantum Break is coming to PC, too|first=Wesley|last=Yin-Poole|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=11 February 2016|accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Players who had not reached 18 years old by the game's release would get ''[[Kameo: Elements of Power]]'' as their pre-order bonus instead.{{efn |''Quantum Break'' is rated [[PEGI]] 16, and ''American Nightmare'' is rated PEGI 18. The higher age restriction of ''American Nightmare'' causes problems with pre-order bonuses.}}<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-04-01-quantum-break-pre-order-offer-replaces-alan-wake-american-nightmare-with-kameo |title=Quantum Break pre-order offer replaces Alan Wake's American Nightmare with Kameo |first=Tom |last=Phillips |work=[[Eurogamer]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> In January 2016, Puha revealed that the game was very close to completion, and that the team was "tired".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ign.com/articles/2016/01/11/quantum-break-so-close-to-completion-says-remedy |title=Quantum Break 'So Close' To Completion, Says Remedy |first=Alex|last=Osborn |work=[[IGN]] |date=11 January 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> On 21 February 2016, Remedy confirmed that the game had [[Software release life cycle#Release to manufacturing (RTM)|gone gold]], indicating it was being prepared for duplication and release.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://m.ign.com/articles/2016/02/19/quantum-break-has-gone-gold |title=Quantum Break Has Gone Gold |first=Matt |last=Potter |work=[[IGN]] |date=19 February 2016 |accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref> Microsoft celebrated the launch with launch parties in various Microsoft stores in the US and Canada, and in Sydney.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/quantum-break-microsoft-launch-parties-livestream-/1100-6436019/ |title=Quantum Break Microsoft Launch Parties, Livestream Event Announced |first=Eddie |last=Makuch |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=25 March 2016 |accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Released alongside the game was a novel titled ''Quantum Break: Zero State''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.kotaku.com.au/2016/07/the-quantum-break-novel-explores-choices-players-couldnt-make/ |title=The Quantum Break Novel Explores Choices Players Couldn't Make |first=Mark |last=Kenney |work=[[Kotaku]] |date=3 July 2016 |accessdate=3 July 2016}}</ref>
A standalone PC version, released through [[Steam (software)|Steam]], and the physical ''Timeless Collector's Edition'' (which includes a development documentary, a book detailing the game's development, a soundtrack CD, and posters) was released on 29 September 2016. Unlike the Windows 10/UWP version, it supports [[Windows 7]] and newer on 64-bit platforms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/quantum-breaks-steam-release-wont-force-you-to-use/1100-6442524/|title=Quantum Break's Steam Release Won't Force You to Use Windows 10|first=Chris|last=Pereira|date=10 August 2016|accessdate=12 August 2016|work=[[GameSpot]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/articles/quantum-break-pc-steam-and-retail-release-delayed/1100-6443259/ | title = Quantum Break PC Steam and Retail Release Delayed | last = Hussain | first = Tamoor | date = 2 September 2016 | website = [[GameSpot]] | publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] | accessdate = 2 September 2016}}</ref> [[THQ Nordic|Nordic Games]], who had assisted the PC distribution of ''Alan Wake'', ''[[Ori and the Blind Forest|Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition]]'', and ''[[State of Decay (video game)|State of Decay: Year-One Survival Edition]]'', distributed the retail copies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-08-10-quantum-break-launches-on-steam-next-month|title=Quantum Break launches on Steam next month|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=10 August 2016|accessdate=11 August 2016}}</ref>

Critical reception for ''Quantum Break'' was divided but generally positive, according to aggregator [[Metacritic]], with the Xbox One version receiving better reviews than the Windows version. Critics generally praised the game's graphics, gameplay and story, but had mixed opinions regarding the game's TV show and the choices featured in the game.
The game's graphics received critical acclaim, with Sam Loveridge from [[Digital Spy]] proclaiming it as one of the "best-looking" video games available for the [[Xbox One]].<ref name="DSpy"/> Critics also praised the game's detailed character models, which makes the game's characters look more lively. Some critics were impressed by the game's various particle effects and destruction mechanics, especially during the stutter moments, which were described as "impressive" by Peter Brown from [[GameSpot]],<ref name="GSpotRev"/> "gorgeous" by David Houghton from [[GamesRadar]],<ref name="GRadarRev"/> and "eye-popping" by Tristan Ogilvie from [[IGN]].<ref name="IGNRev"/> Matt Buchholtz from ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' thought that the locations featured in the game fit the game's atmosphere,<ref name="EGMRev"/> Peter Paras from [[Game Revolution]] criticized them for being too similar to each other.<ref name="GameRevReview"/>
The game's gameplay was positively reviewed, with Buchholtz describing it as one of the game's standout points<ref name="EGMRev"/> It was described it as "fun", "excellent" "exhilarating", "enjoyable" and "quick",<ref name="EGMRev"/><ref name="GRadarRev"/><ref name="VGRev"/> though Ogilvie, Paras and Dean Takahashi from [[VentureBeat]] considered it too easy for players and become repetitive.<ref name="GameRevReview"/><ref name="IGNRev"/><ref name="VBRev"/> Takahashi noted that the variety of time manipulation powers offered to players could be overwhelming, but as they progress, the experience offered is satisfying.<ref name="VBRev"/> Loveridge further added that these powers were addictive.<ref name="DSpy"/> Tom Orry from VideoGamer.com applauded these powers for being "cool" to use,<ref name="VGRev"/> and Ben Reeves from ''[[Game Informer]]'' praised them for adding variety to the game.<ref name="GIRev"/> As powers can be combined to form a chain of attacks, the game was praised for giving players freedom to explore and experiment with them.<ref name="DestructRev"/><ref name="GSpotRev"/> Houghton complained that as most powers were available early on in the game, the development team missed the opportunity to fully "evolve" them.<ref name="GRadarRev"/> The cover system received negative opinions from critics, who complained that they sometimes got stuck in the cover during combat.<ref name="DSpy"/><ref name="PolyRev"/> Brown and Stephen Totilo from [[Kotaku]] thought that the gunplay system was not as refined as the powers, and that the weapons featured were "generic".<ref name="GSpotRev"/><ref name="KotakuRev">{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/quantum-break-the-kotaku-review-1768387991|title=Quantum Break: The Kotaku Review|first=Stephen|last=Totilo|work=[[Kotaku]]|date=5 April 2016|accessdate=17 August 2016}}</ref> Many critics lamented that the final boss character is too hard to defeat, leading to players' frustration.<ref name="GIRev"/><ref name="VBRev"/> The [[Platform game|platforming]] section received mixed reviews. Orry and Arthur Gies from ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' praised them for being "cool" to use and diluting the game's action,<ref name="VGRev"/><ref name="VBRev"/> while Brown and Jeff Gerstmann from [[Giant Bomb]] described them as clumsy and ill-conceived due to the game's loose movement system.<ref name="GSpotRev"/><ref name="GBRev"/><ref name="PCGRev"/>
The game's story received a generally favourable reception. Brett Makedonski from [[Destructoid]] praised it as offering a very entertaining experience and engaging the player from start to finish,<ref name="DestructRev"/> while Takahashi thought that the narration was "ambitious".<ref name="VBRev"/> Orry further added that the story was very "complicated".<ref name="VGRev"/> The game's narrative objects were praised for providing players new insight on the game's story by Buchholtz,<ref name="EGMRev"/> though Houghton and Brown criticized that they broke the flow of gameplay and contain too much significant story information.<ref name="GSpotRev"/><ref name="GRadarRev"/> Some critics believe that as the story progresses with the player's choices, it becomes easier to connect emotionally with the characters. The choices were thought to be important, weighty, and significant, and many claimed that they add replayability to the game<ref name="DSpy"/><ref name="IGNRev"/> and more control to players.<ref name="VBRev"/> Gies added that this approach to choice is new and unique to this game.<ref name="PolyRev"/> However, some critics were disappointed that these choices do not alter the outcome of the story.<ref name="GIRev"/><ref name="GSpotRev"/>
The TV portion of the game received a generally positive reception. Andy Kelly from ''[[PC Gamer]]'' noted its high production values<ref name="PCGRev"/> and Takahashi, Gies and Ogilvie praised the performance of the actors,<ref name="IGNRev"/><ref name="VBRev"/> with Gies singling out Gillen and Reddick as Paul Serene and Martin Hatch respectively.<ref name="PolyRev"/> The perspective offered in the TV series was applauded by Houghton, Loveridge, and Ogilvie for successfully filling many gaps in the story and added additional depth to the game's characters,<ref name="DSpy"/><ref name="GRadarRev"/><ref name="IGNRev"/> as well as humanizing the game's villains according to Gies and Kelly.<ref name="PCGRev"/><ref name="PolyRev"/> Other critics held a completely different opinion, with Paras saying that the show is mediocre and far below the industry's standard, criticizing it for being irrelevant.<ref name="GameRevReview"/> Reeves felt that the show was unnecessary, since the TV characters rarely show up in the game.<ref name="GIRev"/> Both Orry and Buchholtz criticized the show for disconnecting the player from the game, and that the time spent on working on the TV show could have been saved by using in-engine [[cutscene]]s.<ref name="EGMRev"/><ref name="VGRev"/> Peter Brown from [[GameSpot]] criticized the show's dialogue, calling them "cheesy", and obvious product placement. The show's costuming is eccentric, and some critics complained of excessive reuse of props throughout the four episodes.<ref name="GSpotRev"/>
Critics had mixed opinions regarding the overall package. Timothy J. Seppala from ''[[Engadget]]'' considered it "a legitimate reason to buy an Xbox One",<ref>{{cite web| url= https://www.engadget.com/2016/04/07/quantum-break-is-a-legitimate-reason-to-buy-an-xbox-one/ |title='Quantum Break' is a legitimate reason to buy an Xbox One |first=Timothy |last=J. Seppala |work=[[Engadget]] |date=4 July 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> and Loveridge and Gies thought that Remedy had set a foundation for future storytelling by blending the two mediums together, making this game a unique title.<ref name="DSpy"/><ref name="PolyRev"/> Reeves thought that the game had the best gameplay and storytelling of all other Remedy games.<ref name="GIRev"/> Totilo added that the game innovates with the TV show, and that it makes the title something "extraordinary".<ref name="KotakuRev"/> Martin Robinson from [[Eurogamer]] concluded that the game has more style than substance, but recognized the title's uniqueness.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-04-01-quantum-break-review |title=Quantum Break review |first=Martin |last=Robinson |work=[[Eurogamer]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> Both Houghton and Gerstmann agreed that it is an ambitious project,<ref name="GRadarRev"/> However, Gerstmann was disappointed that the elements did not connect well enough<ref name="GBRev"/> and Houghton felt that the complicated format dragged down the game as they were never combined together cohesively.<ref name="GRadarRev"/>
The PC version was poorly received due to numerous performance and stability issues, mostly on [[Nvidia]] [[GPU]]s,<ref name="Hamilton">{{cite web |url= http://www.gamespot.com/articles/quantum-break-on-pc-cant-run-at-60-fps-doesnt-have/1100-6438677/ |title=Quantum Break on PC Can't Run at 60 FPS, Doesn't Have Quit Button |last=Hamilton |first=Kirk |date=8 April 2016 |work=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=9 April 2016}}</ref> along with restrictions imposed by the [[Universal Windows Platform]] that keep users from resorting to third-party workarounds.<ref name="Linneman">{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/digitalfoundry-2016-what-went-wrong-with-quantum-break-pc |title=What went wrong with Quantum Break on PC? |last=Linneman |first=John |date=8 April 2016 |work=[[Eurogamer]] |accessdate=9 April 2016}}</ref> Remedy later announced that they were working actively to fix the issues.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.polygon.com/2016/4/13/11420482/quantum-break-pc-problems-framerate-crashes |title=Studio acknowledges big problems in Quantum Break on PC, says fixes are on the way |first=Owen S. |last=Good |work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]] |date=13 April 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> A Steam release was announced, and this version is compatible with [[Windows 7]] or higher.
===Sales=== According to Aaron Greenberg, an executive at Microsoft, the pre-order sales had exceeded their expectation, and the title has the potential to become a massive success.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.vg247.com/2016/04/01/quantum-break-pre-orders-strong-game-could-be-mega-hit/ |title=Quantum Break pre-orders "really strong", could be a "mega hit," says Greenberg |first=Sherif |last=Saed |work=[[VG247]] |date=1 April 2016 |accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> ''Quantum Break'' was the best-selling retail game in its first week of release in the UK, outselling competitor ''[[Dirt Rally]]'' by 139 sales. It was also the best-selling original property released by Microsoft since the release of Xbox One, outselling games like ''[[Sunset Overdrive]]'', ''[[Ori and the Blind Forest]]'' and ''[[Ryse: Son of Rome]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2016-04-11-quantum-break-uks-best-selling-boxed-game |title=Quantum Break UK's best-selling boxed game |first=Wesley |last=Yin-Poole |work=[[Eurogamer]] |date=11 April 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2016}}</ref>

[[Image:Jerash South Theatre Stage.jpg|thumb|right|240px|The stage of the South Roman theatre in [[Jerash]], [[Jordan]]; the structure at the back is the ''[[scaenae frons]]''.]] In the [[Theatre of Ancient Greece]] and [[classical drama]], the '''''skene''''' was the structure at the back of a theatre stage.The word skene means "tent" or "hut," and it is thought that the original structure for these purposes was a tent or light building of wood, and was a [[temporary structure]].<ref>Broadman, 168</ref> It was initially a very light structure or just cloth hanging from a rope, but over the course of time the skene underwent fundamental changes. First it became a permanent building, whose roof could sometimes be used to make speeches and as time passed it was raised up from the level of the orchestra, creating a proskenion, or "space in front of the ''skene''". The facade of the proskenion was behind the orchestra, and provided a space for supporting stage scenery. During the Roman Period the skene had become a large and complex, elaborately decorated, stone building on several levels. Actors emerged from the skene and could use its steps and balconies to speak from. It was also where costumes were stored and to which the [[periaktoi]] (painted panels serving as the background) were connected.<ref>Perseus</ref> == Classical Greece == Ancient Greek theatre began in the 6th century B.C. and traces its origins to religious rituals such as the Festival of Dionysus and choral odes to the gods known as dithyrambs. Early Greek theaters were simple open air structures built on the slope of a hill. The Theatre of Dionysus Eleuthereus in Athens is thought to have been the first purpose-built theatre. Around the middle of the 5th century B.C. the skene began to appear in Greek Theatre. Placing a skene behind the ''orchestra'' where the performers acted, played, and danced broke what is thought to have been the original [[theatre in the round]] nature of Greek theatre. The skene also served as another "hidden stage." At times some of the action went on inside, in which case it was up to the audience to decide what was happening based on the noises coming from the inside. It was a convention of the dramas of the classic period that characters never died on stage, instead usually retreating into the skene to do so.
"At some point at Athens in the classical period a small stoa colonnade was constructed behind the scene-building with its back to the theater and would have provided a permanent backdrop for the action."<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=A Guide to Ancient Greek Drama|last=Storey|first=Ian|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|year=2005|isbn=|location=Malden, MA|pages=39}}</ref>
== Hellenistic Period == The Hellenistic period started around the time of Alexander the Great's death in 323 B.C. and lasted until the Roman Victory at the Battle of Actium in 31 B.C. As Ancient Greece began to change from a culture consisting of ethnic and city-state Greeks to one governed by large monarchies, theatre architecture to include the stage buildings began to experience significant changes. In the 4th century B.C. the Skene became a permanent stone structure and the stage was raised off the ground. In surviving examples this stage seems to have been raised by 2.43 m to 3.96 m above the orchestra, and to have been from 1.92 m to 3.96 m deep, terminated by the skene.<ref>Grove</ref> As the [[Greek chorus]] declined in importance compared to a smaller group of main actors, the chorus remained in the orchestra to perform, while the main actors generally performed from the stage on top of the proskenion. This important change occurred in the [[Hellenistic period]], between the 3rd and 1st century BC. The skene itself became increasingly elaborate, and was also available as a place for actors to declaim from, so that the performers between them had three levels available. "The roof of the skene was called the ''theologian'' ("god-speaking"), from which one might assume that its primary use was for the advent of deities, either at the start or close of the drama."<ref name=":0" /> Most theaters still standing today date from the Hellenistic period.
== Roman Period == In [[Roman theatre (structure)|Roman theatres]], [[scaenae frons]] ("facade of the skene") is the term for the elaborately decorated stone screens, rising two or three stories, that the skene had now become. By the 1st century BC, the skene was as elaborate as its Roman development which dispensed with the orchestra altogether, leaving a relatively low ''proscaenium'' facade, often decorated, and a wide stage or ''pulpitum'' behind, ending in an elaborate scaenae frons with three or more doors, and sometimes three stories. The evolution of the [[actor]], who assumed an individual part and answered to the chorus (the word for actor, hypokrites, means answerer), introduced into drama a new form, the alternation of acted scenes, or [[episode]]s. The skene no longer supported painted sets in the Greek manner but relied for effect on elaborate permanent architectural decoration and consisted of a series of complex stone buildings. To each side there was a ''paraskenion''. The ''episkenion'' was the upper floor of the skene, which might be deepened to give a third stage level, seen through ''thyromata'' or openings. The interior of the ''logeion'' ("building") behind the skene facade remained normally outside the view of the audience, and fulfilled the original function as a changing room and place for props.
